posts.name:
Matt Bowker
Matt Bowker
posts.content:
Urban infill sites offer great opportunities to build more homes sustainably. For example, we've helped our client transform this site from two dwellings into 10 homes.

We are big fans of urban infill housing developments and here are 8 reasons why:

1️⃣ Efficient Use of Resources:

Infill development maximises existing infrastructure, including roads, utilities, and services; it reduces the need for new construction and minimises costs.

2️⃣ Efficient Use of Land:

By focusing on infill, cities can make more efficient use of previously developed (brownfield) land.

3️⃣ Reduced Urban Sprawl:

By focusing on infill, cities can contain their outward growth to preserve surrounding greenfields and prevent encroachment into natural habitats and agricultural land.

4️⃣ Enhanced Public Transport Accessibility:

Infill sites are typically located near existing public transport networks, promoting the use of mass transit and reducing reliance on cars, which lowers greenhouse gas emissions.

5️⃣ Revitalisation of Underutilised Areas:

Developing infill sites can rejuvenate neglected or declining neighbourhoods, boost local economies, and improve residents' quality of life.

6️⃣ Walkability & Community:

Higher-density developments encourage walkable neighbourhoods, foster community interactions, and reduce dependence on automobiles, which can enhance social cohesion.

7️⃣ Environmental Benefits:

By preserving green spaces and reducing the need for infrastructure expansion, infill development contributes to lower energy consumption, reduced habitat destruction, and supporting biodiversity.

8️⃣ Economic Strengthening:

Infill development can lead to increased property values and tax revenues, providing funds for public services and community enhancements that ultimately benefit the local economy.

These reasons underscore the importance of prioritising urban infill as a strategy for delivering more affordable homes, creating stronger communities, promoting sustainable urban development, and preserving green spaces.

The development shown is the Saplings, a residential development by our client PIC Homes comprising 10 large-family homes in Timperley, Trafford.

posts.name:
Abhijeet Mutha
Abhijeet Mutha
posts.content:
Indians are making lakhs out of Coldplay tickets!


Remember when Coldplay tickets were released in India?

They sold out in seconds.
People were literally in queues to buy them.

And now I see that they are back.

Almost every group that I am in, I see people re-selling these tickets.

But there's a catch.

If they bought it for a few thousands, they are selling it for lakhs now.

And there are buyers at these prices too.

Surprisingly, there's a huge white space for ticket re-selling in India.

Even globally, the secondary ticket market is estimated to be worth $1.74 billion in 2024, and is expected to grow to a massive $3.59 billion by 2032.

While there are a few online platforms that cater to this purpose, I can't recall a dominant player in this area due to the lack of trust and possibility of scams.

Having said that, did you buy the Coldplay tickets?

And if you did, maybe comment below and find someone who's happy to buy it at a resale!

posts.name:
Parasar Saha
Parasar Saha
posts.content:
Solve an industry problem , Build 1 Million Revenue . You will have a story to tell rest of your life.

In the realm of innovation, the journey from idea to reality is a thrill like no other. If you've ever envisioned making a significant impact and charting your course to success, now is the time to heed the call and embark on your entrepreneurial adventure.

Why Initiate Now?

The landscape is ripe with challenges, presenting opportunities to revolutionize entire sectors by addressing inefficiencies and gaps. With the advent of digital tools, global connectivity, and remote collaboration, the path to launching a startup has never been more accessible.

Your breakthrough concept doesn't have to be intricate—it simply needs to address a genuine problem.

The Blueprint for Crafting Your $1 Million Revenue Narrative

1. Recognize the Challenge
Successful startups alleviate pain points. Pay heed to frustrations within your industry, workplace dynamics, or discussions with peers. Often, brilliant ideas are right before our eyes.

Ask yourself:
- What obstacles do I encounter in my role or industry?
- Is there a way to streamline this process for others?

2. Think Small, Dream Large

Progress doesn't demand hefty funding. Begin with a minimum viable product (MVP) that tackles the core issue. Validate your solution with real users, allowing their feedback to steer your evolution.

3. Cultivate Relationships, Not Just Products

Early adopters and partners aren't mere clients—they're your advocates. Foster connections, grasp their needs profoundly, and develop a product experience that fosters trust and loyalty.

4. Embrace Resilience and Adversity

Every entrepreneur encounters obstacles—financial constraints, product refinements, self-doubt. These moments don't signify failure; they sculpt your progress. Successful founders persevere where others falter.

A Story to Tell for the Rest of Your Life
Imagine the pride of looking back and knowing that you created something from scratch—a company that reached $1 million in revenue, transformed lives, and added lasting value. Your journey will be one of growth, impact, and resilience—one that becomes a story worth telling for the rest of your life.

Your Startup Journey Begins Now

Take that first step, however small. You don’t need all the answers—just the courage to start.

comments.commentText: You packed a lot in one post. Thanks for sharing

posts.name:
Alex Nelson
Alex Nelson
posts.content:
First AE hired. Zero pipeline. No playbook. Just me staring at an empty CRM wondering if I'd made a huge mistake.

Here's my honest story of those first 45 days:

• Week 1-2: Studied the product, started running campaigns & doing mock demos.

• Week 3-4: Started taking sales calls some better than others & expanded to other outreach channels.

• Week 5-6: Felt pretty alone at times but started seeing the light at the end of the tunnel. Other AEs had teammates, but I was testing everything by myself.

• Week 7+ (Present): Averaging a little over 6 demos per day & hitting the ground running prospecting every morning

What I learned:
1. Write down everything - my mistakes will help myself & others avoid them
2. Accept the chaos - good systems start messy
3. Make friends first, sell second - early customers help shape everything.

Being first is a challenge for sure but I'm having fun with it.

Founding AEs: What was your biggest "I wish someone told me this" moment?

PS- Happy Friday! Cheers!
